OXEA Bishop LLC, Bishop Facility

Risk Management Plan

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



The information presented in this Risk Management Plan (RMP) represents the OXEA Bishop Facility's implementation of the Environmental Protection Agency Risk Management Program (EPA RMP) regulation.  The EPA RMP regulation covers many elements: hazard assessment, prevention programs, and emergency response programs.  The RMP regulation applies to facilities that use more than specified amounts of certain designated chemicals.  The RMP regulation applies to the OXEA Bishop Facility based on its use of formaldehyde and acetaldehyde.



DESCRIPTION OF THE FACILITY AND REGULATED CHEMICALS

The OXEA Bishop Facility is located between the communities of Kingsville (Kleberg County) and Bishop (Nueces County), Texas.  It is situated in the extreme southwestern corner of Nueces County.  Four employee shifts operate the facility round-the-clock.  The OXEA Bishop Facility has approximately 35 employees and a small force of contract employees.



On March 1, 2007, Advent International purchased a portion of the Celanese Bishop Facility and established the OXEA Bishop Facility.  Prior to that date, the purchased production units were part of the Celanese Bishop Facility and were covered under an RMP filed by Celanese.  The Celanese Bishop Facility began production in 1945 to provide raw materials for its fibers operations on the US East Coast.  The production units now owned by OXEA began production in 1958 and 1960; they have operated continuously since then.



The OXEA Bishop Facility?s units are nestled within the larger Celanese facility which covers approximately 1200 acres.  The OXEA Bishop Facility has two Program Level 3 processes that use several steps (i.e., hydrogenation, separation, etc.) to produce chemical intermediates.  The OXEA products are then are sold to other chemical manufacturers that use the products in their manufacturing processes.  OXEA products are used in the production of

the following types of final products:  polyester, alkyd, and polyurethane resins (plastics); synthetic lubricants; urethane polyols and polymers; multifunctional acrylates and methacrylates for radiation cured coatings; coating and grinding agent for titanium dioxide pigments; polymeric plasticizers; ingredient for cosmetics and personal care products (hand lotion, shampoo, make up remover).



OFF-SITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS RESULTS

Offsite Consequence Analyses for worst-case and alternate-release case are contained in the RMP Sections 2, 3, 4 and 5.  The RMP regulation requires the modeling of releases for a toxic and flammable chemical.  



GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

The following is a summary of the OXEA Bishop Facility accident prevention program.  Because processes at the OXEA Bishop Facility regulated by the EPA RMP regulation are also subject to the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) standard, the summary addresses OSHA PSM elements and describes the management system in place to implement the accident prevention program.



EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION

The OXEA Bishop Facility expects all employees to participate in the PSM program and accident prevention.  It is our belief that the employees operating the equipment are those best equipped to prevent releases.  Employee participation ranges from compiling and updating technical data to participating on process hazard analysis (PHA) and incident investigation teams.  Employees have access to all information related to the accident prevention program and information on accidents themselves.  Specific ways that employees can be involved in the accident prevention program are detailed in the integrated management system that is maintained on an intranet-based management system available to the global OXEA population.  



PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION (PSI)

The OXEA Bishop Facility has a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the facility.  These document

s address chemical properties and associated hazards, safe operating limits for process parameters, chemical inventories, and equipment design information.  The EHS and Technical departments coordinate changes to PSI.



Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards, emergency response, and exposure treatment recommendations, is provided in material safety data sheets (MSDS). Process areas have documented safety-related operating limits for process parameters and strive to ensure that the processes are maintained within these limits by using process control equipment, trained personnel, and protective instrument systems such as level alarms, automated shutdown systems, and pressure relief devices.



OXEA Bishop maintains technical documents that provide design and construction details of the process equipment. Information maintained includes materials of construction, operations specification, design pressure, temperature ratings, and electrical rating. This information combined with written standard operating procedures and personnel training provide a basis for inspection and maintenance activities and the evaluation of proposed changes.



PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS (PHA)

OXEA Bishop uses a comprehensive PHA process to help identify and control hazards associated with production processes.  PHAs are performed on an established schedule, and each process is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure adequate controls are in place to manage identified hazards.  PHAs are revalidated on a five-year frequency.  Details of the PHA process are available to all OXEA employees in the intranet based integrated management system.  



The OXEA PHA process uses a variety of tools to identify process hazards, accident prevention, and mitigation measures.  The PHA is conducted by a team of operations and maintenance personnel, operations engineers, and process engineers.  Technical consultants are used as necessary. 



The PHA team findings and recommen

dations to address identified hazards are forwarded to management to coordinate further evaluation and resolution.  Implementation of the recommendations is prioritized based on relative risk and resolution plans are tracked until completed. Final resolution of each finding is documented and retained for future reference.



OPERATING PROCEDURES

OXEA Bishop maintains written standard operating procedures (SOPs) that detailing the different production units? operating modes and provide guidance on how to respond to an exceedance of operating limits for specific equipment or process parameters. SOPs are available to operators and other personnel to use as necessary to safely perform assigned tasks. SOPs provide a basis for training operators.  Procedures are revised as needed to reflect changes made through the management of change process.



TRAINING

OXEA Bishop trains employees that will operate the process equipment.  The program involves guided study, independent study, and on-the-job training.  Operators must demonstrate that they have the skills to operate process equipment safely and correctly before they are allowed to work independently.  Operators receive refresher training on a specified schedule.  Training is documented.  Details on the technical training program for operators are available to all employees via the OXEA integrated management system.



CONTRACTORS

OXEA Bishop supplements its workforce by using contractors to perform some routine maintenance and packaging.  Contractors are also used during periods of increased maintenance or construction activity.  In order to work for OXEA, contractors must have safety programs at least as stringent as OXEA's.   OXEA Bishop has implemented procedures to assist contractors perform their work in a safe manner, ensure they have the appropriate knowledge and skills, are aware of workplace hazards, understand what they should do should an emergency occur, understand and follow safety rules, and inform OXEA

personnel of any hazards they find during their work. This is accomplished by providing contractors an orientation prior to their working on this plant.  OXEA also uses a documented Safe Work Permit process to ensure that the job is evaluated for hazards and that those hazards are mitigated prior to commencing work.  



OXEA personnel routinely monitor contractor job performance to help ensure they are fulfilling their safety obligations. Contractor safety programs and performance are evaluated during the selection process and are reviewed periodically by facility EHS and management.



PRE-STARTUP SAFETY REVIEWS (PSSR)

OXEA uses a PSSR process to review modifications that cause a significant change in the process safety information. The PSSR will help ensure safety features, procedures, personnel, and equipment are prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment into service. The PSSR provides an additional opportunity to check that construction was executed as specified in the design and all supporting systems are ready. The PSSR involves construction field verification.



MECHANICAL INTEGRITY (MI)

OXEA Bishop uses established practices and procedures to maintain process and support equipment in a safe operating condition. The MI program includes training, inspections, correction of deficiencies, and quality assurance of work products.  Maintenance personnel are trained on the process, safety and health hazards, maintenance procedures, emergency procedures, and safe work processes to help ensure that they execute their jobs safely.  Documented equipment files and maintenance histories help maintain consistent performance of repairs. 



Inspections and preventive maintenance are performed on a scheduled basis to ensure equipment and safety devices function as intended and to verify that equipment is within acceptable limits.  Deficiencies are corrected before placing the equipment back into service or technical experts review continued use of the equipment

to determine what actions are needed to ensure safe operation until the deficiency can be corrected.





SAFE WORK PROCESSES

OXEA Bishop uses an established safe work permit process to ensure worker and process safety. Orientations are provided for all visitors and contractors.  The facility has controlled access for employees, visitors, and contractors.  Work on specific equipment is governed by a job permitting system to ensure that all hazards are identified and addressed prior to commencing work.  These safe work processes, supporting procedures, and training on the processes ensure that maintenance activities are safely performed. 



MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE (MOC)

OXEA Bishop has a comprehensive and mature management of change system. It requires that changes to process equipment, chemicals, operating technology, procedures, and other changes be reviewed and authorized before implementation. Changes are reviewed to ensure controls are in place to manage new hazards and verify that no existing controls have been compromised.  Changes are documented on corresponding chemical hazard lists, process operating parameters, equipment files, and procedures.  Affected personnel are trained on the changes to be implemented. 



INCIDENT INVESTIGATION

OXEA Bishop documents and investigates all incidents that resulted in (or could have reasonably resulted in) a fire, explosion, release, major damage to property or equipment, environmental release / damage, or personal injury. The investigation strives to record the facts of the incident and identify how to prevent recurrence.   Incident information, including required corrective actions, is maintained in an electronic database available to all OXEA employees.  Corrective actions are tracked until completed and final resolution is documented.  Incident investigation data is reviewed at the next scheduled PHA or revalidation.



COMPLIANCE AUDITS

OXEA Bishop conducts audits PSM programs once every three years.   The purpos

e of the audit is to determine if the PSM program processes are being effectively implemented.  The audit team consists of facility and technical staff.  Deficiencies identified during the audit are documented and forwarded to management for resolution.  Corrective actions are implemented to address findings and resolution status is tracked to completion.  Final resolution is documented.  Final reports of audits are retained per the company records retention policy. 



CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

OXEA Bishop processes have hazards that are managed to help ensure continued safe operation. The following is a description of existing safety features applicable to the prevention of accidental releases of the specific regulated substances (i.e., flammables).



Universal Prevention Activities

The accident prevention program summarized previously is applied throughout the facility.  In the area of the plant subject to the RMP regulation, this program helps prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and human errors.



Specialized Features

This plant has safety equipment / features throughout the production units to detect a release, control a release, and reduce the consequences of a release. 



Release detection is accomplished by the use of alarms on unit control panels to indicate releases on key equipment, and high and low level alarms on storage equipment.  Releases are controlled by the use of pressure relief devices that discharge to atmosphere and boiler system; manual and automatic isolation valves; automated shut down systems for key equipment; and redundant equipment.  The impact of releases are reduced or mitigated by the use of fire extinguishing systems, personal protective equipment for affected personnel, secondary containment, process fluid isolation sumps, and access to on-site emergency response team.



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

OXEA Bishop had one (1) incidents / accidents that meet the RMP regulation

definition of accident.  As noted earlier, OXEA Bishop maintains all incident history in a database available to all employees.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION

OXEA Bishop maintains a joint emergency response plan with the Celanese Bishop facility.  Celanese Bishop provides administrative coordination for the emergency plan and emergency response personnel; OXEA Bishop provides emergency response personnel for each shift.  The emergency plan is designed to protect employees, the public, and the environment. The plan addresses many emergency scenarios but those of specific importance to the RMP are the scenarios dealing with releases of regulated chemicals, including fires and explosions.  The emergency plan is reviewed annually and revised as needed. Changes triggered by the Management of Change process are administered per that specific program and include training of affected personnel. 



The Bishop complex emergency response program is coordinated with the Corpus Christi / Nueces County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC), City of Bishop Volunteer Fire Department, Kingsville Fire Department, Kleberg County Sheriff's Department, and local ambulance services. The OXEA Bishop Facility has 24-hour communications capability with the emergency response organizations.  Periodic emergency plan drills are conducted and an annual evacuation drill is conducted for all employees.  The emergency response team members train on a continual basis.
